The 'positron' or 'antielectron' is the antiparticle or the antimatter
counterpart of the electron. The positron has an electric charge of +1e, a spin
of Â½, and has the same mass as an electron. When a low-energy positron collides
with a low-energy electron, annihilation occurs, resulting in the production of
two or more gamma ray photons (see electronâpositron annihilation).

Positrons may be generated by positron emission radioactive decay (through weak
interactions), or by pair production from a sufficiently energetic photon.
